column1: + System behaviour that appears to be (partially) coordinated by previously 'experienced events'

+ The solution to a difference or differential equation allows one to find any state of the system without the need to iterate the model starting from some initial condition. There are very few (systems of) equations for which analytical solutions exist
+ The status that a dynamic system eventually "settles down to". An attractor is a set of values in the phase space to which a system migrates over time
column2: or iterations. Attractors can have as many dimensions as the number of variables that influence its system

column1: + A region in phase space associated with a given attractor. The basin of attraction of an attractor is the set of all (initial) points that eventually end up in that attractor
+ The  temporal evolution of states of a system according to one or more rules (also known as state propagation rules
column2: or
column3: iterative processes). Models of the behaviour of dynamic systems use difference or differential equations to describe the iterative processes hypothesized to underlie the temporal evolution

column1: + A clearly observable qualitative change in the behavioural mode (attractor state) of a dynamic system associated with continuous change in one or more control parameters  (also known as Phase-
column2: State-
column3: or Order- Transition). The value of a control parameter at which a bifurcation occurs is often non-specific

column1: + Visual summary of the succession of period-doubling bifurcations produced by gradual changes in the control parameter(s)
+ Markers indicative for a physical system that is described by a catastrophe. There are 5 'classical' flags and 3 'diagnostic' flags. Classical: bimodality
column2: sudden jumps
column3: inaccessibility
column4: sensitivity & hysteresis. Diagnostic: divergence from linear response
column5: critical slowing down and critical  fluctuations. Diagnostic flags can be used as early-warning signals.

column1: + Mathematical research program describing how gradual change in some parameters can lead to disproportionately large changes in another parameter
column2: called catastrophes (similar to bifurcations
column3: Phase-
column5: or Order-transitions). 'This kind of behaviour has been summarized succinctly in the phrase "the straw that broke the camel's back".' (Gilmore

column1: + A network with of many nodes and likely many substructures depending on that nature and distribution of connections between nodes
+ Spatially and/or temporally extended nonlinear systems characterized by emergent properties and self-organised behavioural modes at a global
column2: or
column3: macro-level (the system as a whole)
column4: that is often different from the characteristic behaviour at a local
column6: micro-level (behaviour of the individual parts that constitute the whole)

column1: + Complexity science studies how systems that consist of many components can generate relatively simple and stable (non-random) behaviour. Important behavioural phenomena studied in Complexity Science are synchronisation
column2: adaptation and coordination of behaviour across many different temporal and spatial scales
column3: emergent properties and collective behaviour

column1: + A causal ontology in which observed behaviour is explained by assuming it is the result of a chain of independent efficient causes (components)
+ A variable that controls the global behaviour of a dynamic system. For certain values of the parameter
column2: transitions between qualitatively different behavioural modes (orders) can occur.

column1: + An early warning signal for a phase transition that is characterised by an increase in fluctuations (variability) of the behaviour of the system. The increase occurs because the self-organised transition from one state to another relaxes the constraints on the degrees of freedom a system has available to generate its behaviour
column2: allowing states and behavioural modes to appear that were previously inaccessible.

column1: + An early warning signal for a phase transition that is characterised by an increase in the duration of relaxation times. If it takes longer for the system to return to the state it was perturbed from
column2: this implies the emergence of a new stable state is imminent

column1: + Behaviour of a dynamic system that "looks random
column2: but is not" (Lorenz
column3: 1973). The dynamics can be characterised as follows: 1) A-periodic
column4: no point or trajectory in state space will exactly recur; 2) Sensitive dependence in initial conditions; 3) Bounded
column5: not all theoretically possible degrees of freedom are available to the system; 4) The origin of this behaviour is deterministic

column1: + A function specifying the underlying change process in a variable from one discrete point in time to another
+ A function specifying the underlying change process of a variable in continuous  time

column2: box-counting dimension
column3: correlation dimension

column1: + The set of variables that define a system. Iterative processes operate on the dimensions of a system

+ A set of equations specifying how certain variables change over time. The equations specify how to determine (compute) the new values as a function of their current values and control parameters. The functions
column2: when explicit
column3: are either difference equations or differential equations. Dynamic systems may be stochastic or deterministic. In a stochastic system
column4: new values come from a probability distribution. In a deterministic system
column5: a single new value is associated with any current value

column1: + Critical slowing down and critical fluctuations. Early-warning signals indicate instability in the existing state which may result in a qualitative shift towards a new state (phase transition / catastrophe). Early-warning signals are similar to diagnostic catastrophe flags.
+ “The effective complexity of an entity is the length of a highly compressed description of its regularities.” (Gell-man & Lloyd
+ Successive N-tuples of points in a time series are treated as points in N dimensional space. The points are said to reside in embedding dimensions of size N
column2: for N = 1

column1: + A complex system can generate emergent behaviour or display emergent properties that are novel and unexpected
column2: that is
column3: they are not predictable from the behaviour and properties of the components of the system

column1: + Relative absence of order/redundancy in a system. The degrees of freedom a system has available for generating its behaviour: Possibility
+ A hypothetical landscape describing the relative stability of behavioural modes of a system over time

+ An interaction of a system with its environment that changed the internal structure/organization of the system such that it can be said to display adaptive behaviour. “Interaction with after-effects”. Random behaviour is “Interaction without after-effects”.
+ An irregular shape with self-similarity. It has infinite detail
column2: and cannot be differentiated. "Wherever chaos
column3: turbulence
column5: fractal geometry is at play" (Briggs and Peat

column1: + A measure of a geometric object that can take on fractional values. At first used as a synonym to Hausdorff dimension
column2: fractal dimension is currently used as a more general term for a measure of how fast length
column3: area
column4: or volume increases with decrease in scale. (Peitgen

column1: + Models in which associations between mathematical objects are defined as edges (connections) between vertices (nodes)
+ A measure of a geometric object that can take on fractional values. (see fractal dimension).
+ "some property of a whole would be holistic if
column2: according to the theory in question
column3: there is no way we can find out about it using only local means
column5: by using only all possible non-holistic resources available to an agent.” (Seevinck

column1: + Scientific explanation in which the goal is to generate knowledge about specific facts
column2: events or entities. The goal is not to generalize to universal laws and first principles.

column1: + A measurable quantity that resolves uncertainty about the state of a system by assigning a value to the uncertainty.
+ The starting point of a dynamic system
column2: the initial state of a system from which it evolved to the current state.

column1: + A causal ontology in which observed behaviour is explained by assuming it is the result of interactions between processes across many temporal and spatial scales
+ The repeated application of a function
column2: using its output from one application as its input for the next.

column1: + A function used to calculate the new state of a dynamic system.
+ A system in which one or more functions are iterated to define the system.
+ The value of the largest exponent in a spectrum of exponents (the Lyapunov spectrum)
column2: coefficients of time
column3: that reflect the rate of departure (divergence) of dynamic orbits of a system. The largest exponent indicates the extent to which the behaviour of a system is sensitive to initial conditions.

column1: + An attractor that is periodic in time
column2: that is
column3: that cycles periodically through an ordered sequence of states.

column1: + Points in phase space. There are three kinds: attractors
column2: repellors
column3: and saddle points. A system moves away from repellors and towards attractors. A saddle point is both an attractor and a repellor
column4: it attracts a system in certain regions
column5: and repels the system to other regions.

column1: + A linear equation is of predictors is of the form y=a*x(i)+b
column2: in which variable y varies 'linearly' with other variables x(i). In this equation
column3: 'a' determines the slope of the line and 'b' reflects the y-intercept
column4: the value y obtains when all x(i) equal zero.

column1: + A linear function of time is of the form ŷ(t) = a*y(t) + b
column2: in which variable y varies 'linearly' with time 't'
column3: that is
column4: with itself at an earlier moment in time. In this equation 'a' determines the rate with which 'y' will change as time passes
column6: the value y obtains when t equals zero.

column1: + The study of dynamic systems whose functions specify that change is not a linear function of time.
+ A sequence of coordinates (a path) through the phase space of a system.
+ “order is essentially the arrival of redundancy in a system
column2: a reduction of possibilities”(Von Förster
column3: 2003). Any form of non-random association or dependency that exists between parts of a system
column4: its behaviour over time and/or its environment is a form of order. In scientific explanation of behaviour
column5: the presence of order in non-artificial systems must be explained and should not be (implicitly) assumed.

column1: + A nominal variable that indexes qualitatively different behavioural modes of a system
column2: for example the phases of matter (gas
column3: liquid

column1: + The change in dynamics in which a N-point attractor is replaced by a 2N-point attractor.
+ The collection of all trajectories from all possible starting points in the phase space of a dynamic system.

+ An abstract space used to represent the behaviour of a system. Its dimensions are the variables of the system. Thus a point in the phase space defines a potential state of the system. The points actually achieved by a system depend on its iterative function and initial condition (starting point).
+ A transition between qualitatively different behavioural modes
+ A function that describes the order parameter of a system
column2: that is
column3: it describes the relative stability of the potential end-states (attractor states) a system can settle into. The parameters of the potential function include the control parameter.

column1: + A relationship between two variables that is linear on doubly logarithmic coordinates
column2: meaning the law is expressed in increments that represent 'power'
"recursive" and "iterative" are synonyms. Thus recursive processes are iterative processes
column3: and recursive functions are iterative functions.

column1: + The time it takes for a system to return to a stable state after it was perturbed enough to leave that state. A characteristic warning signal of an imminent phase transition is an increase relaxation times
column2: also known as critical slowing down.

column1: + One type of limit point. A point in phase space that a system moves away from.
+ Plot of time series values vs. a delayed copy of itself. A return plot can be used to get an idea about the functional form of the iterative process
column2: it is a simple variant of delay embedding.
usually in three dimensional state space
column3: that both attracts and repels
column4: attracting in one dimension and repelling to another.

column1: + A network in which the distribution of the number of connections of a node and their frequency of occurrence follows a power-law in which there are just a few nodes with many connections and many nodes with just a few connections
+ An infinite nesting of characteristic structure on all scales. Strict self-affinity refers to a form of which all substructures are affine transformation
column2: which means the different dimensions of the system can be scaled by their own exponent. Statistical self-affinity refers to an approximate equivalence of form at all scales.

column1: + An infinite nesting of characteristic structure on all scales. Strict self-similarity refers to a form of which all substructures can be considered scaling transformations
column2: larger or smaller copies scaled by a single exponent for all dimensions of the structure. Statistical self-similarity refers to an approximate equivalence of scaled structure.

column1: + A property of chaotic systems. A dynamic system has sensitivity to initial conditions when very small differences in starting values result in very different behaviour. If the orbits of nearby starting points diverge
column2: the system has sensitivity to initial conditions.

column1: + Many real-world networks have a small average shortest path length
column2: but also a clustering coefficient that is significantly higher than expected by chance. These networks are extremely efficient
column3: each node in a very large network can still be reach in just a few steps (the 'six degrees of separation` phenomenon).

column1: + A coordinate in state space designating the current status of a dynamic system. The elements of the coordinates are values on the dimensions of the system that span the state space.
+ A hypothetical space spanned by the dimensions of the system. Each combination of values of variables that represent the dimension is a state of the system
column2: it is a coordinate in state space.

column1: + An abstract space used to represent the behaviour of a system. Its dimensions are the variables of the system. Thus a point in the phase space defines a potential state of the system.
+ An attractor state representing chaotic dynamics: a-periodic
column2: bounded
column3: and sensitive dependence on initial conditions

column1: + An entity that can be described as a composition of components according to some organising principle. Organising principles describe how parts of the system relate to the whole and.
+ A record of observations (data points) of behaviour over time.
+ A sequence of positions (path) of a system in its phase space. The path from its starting point (initial condition) to and within its attractor.
+ The time it takes for a system to transition from one stable state (behavioural mode
column2: attractor state) into another
column3: during which the system displays transient behaviour
